reference: Is there a limit to immune system "memory"? - Nope. Your immune system is in contact with 100s to 1000s of things daily (from your skin, your gut, your kids, the air, etc.) and has space to categorize all those on a harmful-harmless scale. Sometimes it gets stuff wrong (see: allergies), sometimes it gets too excited (see: autoimmune), sometimes it forgets what it learned prior. But it can always learn new things, even if it slows down on how well it learns those. How many different things can someone be vaccinated for? - There's no real top limit here. Again, your immune system encounters exponentially more out in the world than it does through vaccines. We decide what to vaccinate for based on what's available, what's common/contagious enough, and prior evidence of when individual protection wears thin. But there are more bacterial cells on/in your body than there are human cells. Your immune system has plenty of space. :) Do the older vaccinations wear off as new vaccinations are received, or do they fade away by age or something else? - Older vaccinations of some subtypes can "wear off" or separately become less effective, but this is more a product of the type of vaccine and the disease agent itself, not the immune system filling up. For instance, most people never need MMR again after a 2-shot series (some even have full immunity after 1 shot), same for HiB vaccines and polio. However, we know the tetanus and pertussis components of the Tdap/DTap vaccine do wane over time, lasting 5-10 years each, so we booster that pretty regularly in adults. Other vaccines covered a previous variant of the illness but not the current circulating one (see: flu), so we give a new one to help train the immune system on the new one. What fades and why is complicated and has some to do with what specific parts we are vaccinating for (i.e., for tetanus and pertussis it's actually a toxoid vaccine, where we train the immune system to recognize the bacterial product and not the bacteria itself) as well as other things above my paygrade. Can an immune system get "full" like computer memory? IE If I get a flu shot does the Hepatitis vaccine from years ago get forgotten or does everything just keep adding on to "things I have an immunity to"? - No, the immune system doesn't get full. It can forget things for a variety of reasons, or it can fail to respond to a vaccine in the first place (one the reasons some of the childhood shots are series is that a certain percentage of people have immunity after one shot while a larger group is fully protected after 2). These are all kind of variations on a theme, so just to repeat the theme - your immune system encounters an incredible number of pathogens a day, no matter how spotless you keep yourself and your house. Your immune system is far, far more challenged by those than any number of vaccinations we could potentially give you. It literally evolved just for that purpose, in a world where there were even more parasites, bacteria, viruses and the like.
